about.intro: My name is Christian Gefke, and I am an authorized lawyer (member number 635 of the Lanzarote Bar Association) with a solid education and extensive experience in law. I was born in Aarhus, Denmark, but grew up in Lanzarote, the Canary Islands.
about.introEnglish: Spanish lawyer in Aarhus – Christian Gefke is an officially registered abogado with the Colegio de Abogados de Lanzarote (No. 635). He provides expert legal assistance in Spanish property law, inheritance, family law, contracts, and cross-border matters for clients in Denmark and Spain. Fully verified in the CGAE national lawyer registry, he offers reliable guidance for anyone needing a Spanish lawyer in Aarhus or legal help related to Spain.

I then completed a master's degree at Universidad Internacional de la Rioja (UNIR), where I specialized in real estate acquisition. In 2022, I passed the national bar exam held annually by the Spanish Ministry of Justice, which gave me the right to join a local bar association – a necessary condition in Spain to practice law in court.
about.career: Throughout my career, I have had the opportunity to work with several prominent companies, such as Grupo Stier, one of the leading players in the port of Las Palmas, as well as Grupo Martinez in real estate and retail in Spain. In addition, I have collaborated with a wide range of independent consultants, accountants, economists and lawyers.
about.passion: My passion for law arises primarily in private law, where this as an evolving reality brings important lessons when society is presented with new challenges – whether it concerns new technologies or old institutions with new characteristics.
about.closing: I am here to offer you high-quality legal advice and help you navigate the complex legal world with confidence and security.

testamenter.metaDescription: Get help with will spain and inheritance spain dane. Avoid Spanish forced inheritance and secure the distribution of your inheritance with professional legal advice.
testamenter.ogTitle: Will Spain: What Danes should know about inheritance
testamenter.ogDescription: Secure your inheritance with a will in Spain. Read about forced inheritance, tax liability and the benefits of choosing Danish law.
testamenter.twitterTitle: Will Spain: Why Danes should take a stand
testamenter.twitterDescription: A will in Spain is crucial for Danes who want control over the distribution of their inheritance. Avoid Spanish forced inheritance.
testamenter.title: Will Spain: Inheritance and forced inheritance for Danes
testamenter.subtitle: Understand the importance of a will for Danes living in Spain, and how to avoid Spanish forced inheritance and tax pitfalls.
testamenter.section1Title: 1. Why is a will important in Spain?
testamenter.section1Text: In Spain, it is essential for all foreign citizens, including Danes, to create a will to ensure correct distribution of assets and property. Without a will, Spanish inheritance law will automatically apply, which often conflicts with Danish expectations.
testamenter.section2Title: 2. Spanish inheritance law and forced inheritance (la legítima)
testamenter.section2Text: Spanish inheritance law contains rules on forced inheritance, where at least 2/3 of the inheritance must go to the closest heirs – typically children or parents. Only one third of the inheritance can the testator freely dispose of.
testamenter.section2Text2: This can mean that spouses and other close relatives do not inherit as desired – unless there is a valid will.
testamenter.section3Title: 3. Example: A Dane without a will
testamenter.section3Text: Imagine Peter, a Danish man living in Alicante, married to a Spanish spouse. Peter wants the entire estate to go to her. Without a will:
testamenter.section3Item1: 2/3 will go to his adult children in Denmark as forced inheritance
testamenter.section3Item2: Only 1/3 will be available to the spouse – and only with a will
testamenter.section3Item3: The spouse gets usufruct, but not ownership of the property
testamenter.section3Text2: In Denmark, Peter could bequeath up to 75% to the spouse. The Danish model is much more flexible.
testamenter.section4Text: Without proper inheritance planning, heirs risk being taxed in both Denmark and Spain. A will with clear basis in Danish law can prevent double taxation and ensure documentation.
testamenter.conclusionTitle: Conclusion: Ensure legal clarity with a will
testamenter.conclusionText: A will is not just a formality – it is a necessity for Danes in Spain who want control over the distribution of their inheritance and to secure their loved ones.
testamenter.conclusionItem1: Avoid unwanted distribution under Spanish law
testamenter.conclusionItem2: Designate Danish law as applicable via EU inheritance regulation
testamenter.conclusionItem4: Secure spouse and family legally and emotionally
testamenter.conclusionText2: Do you have questions about wills in Spain?

realkredit.section3Text: Most Danish property buyers finance with bank loans. The bank then requires a mortgage as security.
realkredit.section3ExampleText: You buy a property for 250,000 EUR in Alicante and finance 70%. The bank gets a mortgage. If the loan defaults, the bank can demand foreclosure.

realkredit.section4Item1: Review of loan agreements and mortgage terms

lawChoice.metaDescription: When can Danish inheritance law be applied to a foreign estate? Get insight into choice of law rules and will choices in international inheritance cases.
lawChoice.ogTitle: Choice of law in international inheritance cases – When can Danish inheritance law be applied?
lawChoice.ogDescription: Get clarity on when Danish inheritance law can be applied in international estates. Read about wills, choice of law and EU rules.
lawChoice.title: Choice of law in international inheritance cases – When can Danish inheritance law be applied to a foreign estate?
lawChoice.subtitle: A legal review of the possibilities for choosing Danish law in cross-border inheritance cases.
lawChoice.section1Text1: When a Danish citizen dies abroad, the question arises as to which country's inheritance law should apply. This depends on the rules on
lawChoice.section1Text2: Here we review the Danish and European rules, how wills affect the choice of inheritance law, and what happens with invalid choice of law.
lawChoice.section2Title: 2. What is choice of law in inheritance law?
lawChoice.section2Text1: Choice of law determines which country's inheritance rules apply – not which court handles the case.
lawChoice.section2ExampleText: A Dane dies in Spain. If no choice of law has been made, Spanish inheritance law applies. If Danish inheritance law is chosen in a will, Danish inheritance law is used – but the case is still handled in Spain.
lawChoice.section2Text2: Danish law allows choice of Danish inheritance law if the testator was a Danish citizen at the time of death.
lawChoice.section3Title: 3. EU Inheritance Regulation and Choice of Law
lawChoice.section3Text1: As a main rule, the inheritance law of the deceased's
lawChoice.section3Text2: Exception: The testator can choose their
lawChoice.section3Text2Text: (article 22) – e.g. Danish law for a Danish citizen.
lawChoice.section3Text3: Denmark has a legal reservation, but typically recognizes choice of law made under the regulation.
lawChoice.section4Title: 4. Can you always choose Danish inheritance law?
lawChoice.section4Item1: The choice must appear clearly in the will
lawChoice.section4Item2: The testator must be a Danish citizen
lawChoice.section4Item3: The processing country must accept the EU regulation
lawChoice.section4TextText: Danish law after death if it is not stated in a will.
lawChoice.section5Title: 5. If the deceased has chosen Danish law in a will
lawChoice.section5Text1: The inheritance is distributed according to Danish rules – but the case can still be handled abroad.
lawChoice.section5Text2: The choice of law can be overridden if:
lawChoice.section5Item1: The will is not valid in the country of residence
lawChoice.section5Item2: There is doubt about citizenship or intent
lawChoice.section5Item3: The wording in the will is unclear
lawChoice.section5ExampleText: A Dane in France chooses Danish inheritance law. France recognizes the choice, but handles the case in French probate court.
lawChoice.section6Title: 6. If no choice of law has been made
lawChoice.section6Text1: Without a will, the inheritance rules of the country of residence apply (article 21).
lawChoice.section6Text2: Danish law can only come into play if there are assets in Denmark – and only for these.
lawChoice.section7Title: 7. What if the choice of law proves invalid?
lawChoice.section7Text1: A choice of law can be invalid if:
lawChoice.section7Item1: The testator was not a Danish citizen
lawChoice.section7Item3: The choice of law is unclear or the testator was incompetent
lawChoice.section7Text2: In that case, the inheritance law of the country of residence applies, and the heirs have limited opportunity to change this.
lawChoice.conclusionItem1: Choice of law determines inheritance law – not probate
lawChoice.conclusionItem2: Danish inheritance law can be chosen, but only in a valid will
lawChoice.conclusionItem3: Without choice of law, the rules of the country of residence apply
lawChoice.conclusionItem4: Legal advice is crucial to ensure validity
lawChoice.conclusionText: Do you want Danish inheritance law in an international inheritance case? Contact us and get help with correct formulation of will and securing your heirs' rights.

divorce.section1Text1Text: (Brussels II-ter) Spanish courts can handle a divorce case if:
divorce.section1Item1: Both spouses have habitual residence in Spain
divorce.section1Item2: One spouse lives in Spain and files the application
divorce.section1Item3: Spain was the last common country of residence, and one still lives there
divorce.section1Text2: Two Danish citizens can therefore get divorced in Spain, even if the marriage was entered into in Denmark, as long as there is a real connection.
divorce.section2Title: Which law applies to the divorce itself?
divorce.section2Text1Text: (Rome III) spouses can choose which law applies:
divorce.section2Item4: Country where the case is filed (Spain)
divorce.section2Text2: If not chosen, the above order is automatically applied.
divorce.section2Text3: Important: This law only applies to the dissolution – not to the financial settlement.

divorce.section3Text1: The finances between spouses are regulated by
divorce.section3Item3: First common country of residence law

divorce.section5Text1: allows support in case of financial imbalance after divorce. The court assesses:
divorce.section5Text2: is determined according to Spanish law and EU regulation 4/2009.
divorce.section6Title: Recognition of divorce in other countries

I also deliver legal services to Spaniards in Spain, as well as Danes in Denmark, i.e. not only to Danes in Spain.

I hold both the title of lawyer and jurist, which means I can offer a wide range of legal services. These should primarily be seen as complementary to each other, as lawyer services typically involve representation in court, while jurist services include advice, document handling and other legal tasks outside the courtroom.

My approach is always personal and targeted at understanding your specific needs and circumstances. Whether you need help with property transactions, family law matters, business formation or tax questions, I work closely with you to ensure you get the most effective solution.

In addition, I have built an extensive network of professional partners, including real estate agents, auditors and other specialists. This means I can offer you a holistic service that covers all aspects of your project in Spain.

My multilingualism and cultural understanding of both Denmark and Spain make me the ideal partner for Danish clients who want professional legal assistance in Spain.

**Factors affecting the timeframe:**
- Completeness of documentation
- Workload of authorities
- Complexity of the case
- International elements
- Language barriers

I always keep you informed about progress and any delays, and work proactively to minimize processing time where possible.
